title: Problem Overview
content: This module formalizes **Erdos Problem #24**: Does every triangle-free graph on 5n vertices contain at most n^5 copies of C5? The answer is **YES**, proved independently by Grzesik (2012) and Hatami et al. (2013).
mathContext: The problem asks for the maximum number of pentagons (5-cycles) in a triangle-free graph. The extremal graph is the balanced blow-up of C5, which achieves exactly n^5 copies. The proof uses Razborov's flag algebras.

title: Triangle-Free Graphs
content: A graph is **triangle-free** if it contains no K3 (complete graph on 3 vertices). Equivalently, G.CliqueFree 3. This is the same as having girth >= 4.
mathContext: Triangle-freeness is a fundamental constraint in extremal graph theory. It prevents local clustering and forces graphs toward specific structures. In our case, it forces pentagon-like patterns.

title: The 5-Cycle Graph C5
content: The **5-cycle graph** C5 has vertices 0, 1, 2, 3, 4 with edges forming a cycle: 0--1--2--3--4--0. We define adjacency as (x+1) mod 5 = y or (y+1) mod 5 = x.
mathContext: C5 is the smallest odd cycle that can exist in a triangle-free graph (since C3 = K3 is forbidden). The pentagon structure is central to this problem.

title: C5 Copy Definition
content: A **C5 copy** in graph G is an injective function f : Fin 5 -> V such that adjacent vertices in C5 map to adjacent vertices in G. This is an injective graph homomorphism.
mathContext: Counting subgraph copies is central to extremal combinatorics. The injectivity ensures we count induced pentagons, not just homomorphic images.

title: Counting C5 Copies
content: The function **countC5** counts unordered C5 copies in a graph. We divide by 10 because each pentagon can be traced from 5 starting vertices in 2 directions.
mathContext: The 10-fold symmetry (D5 dihedral group) means each unordered pentagon corresponds to 10 ordered copies. Using classical we sidestep decidability issues.

title: Balanced Blow-Up of C5
content: The **balanced blow-up** replaces each vertex of C5 with an independent set of n vertices. Two vertices are adjacent iff their corresponding parts are adjacent in C5.
mathContext: This construction has 5n vertices, is triangle-free (C5 has no K3), and achieves exactly n^5 copies of C5 (one choice per part). It's the unique extremal graph.

title: Blow-Up is Triangle-Free
content: The balanced blow-up of C5 is **triangle-free**. A triangle would require three mutually adjacent parts, but C5 contains no K3.
mathContext: This follows directly from C5 being triangle-free. The blow-up inherits this property since adjacency only depends on part adjacency, not within-part structure.

title: Grzesik-Hatami Pentagon Theorem
content: **Main Theorem**: Every triangle-free graph on 5n vertices contains at most n^5 copies of C5. The proof uses Razborov's flag algebras, a computer-assisted method.
mathContext: Flag algebras convert extremal problems to semidefinite programs. The key is encoding graph constraints as polynomial inequalities and using SDP solvers to verify bounds.

title: Uniqueness of Extremal
content: The balanced blow-up is the **unique extremal graph**. Any triangle-free graph on 5n vertices with exactly n^5 copies of C5 must be isomorphic to the blow-up.
mathContext: Extremal uniqueness is a strong structural result. It says there's only one way to achieve the maximum, not just that a maximum exists.

title: Gyori's Earlier Bound
content: **Gyori** proved an earlier bound of 1.03n^5 before flag algebras. This was improved by Furedi, but neither achieved the sharp bound n^5.
mathContext: The progression 1.03n^5 -> improved -> n^5 shows how extremal problems often require new techniques. Flag algebras were the breakthrough that gave the sharp answer.

title: Erdos's General Conjecture
content: **General Conjecture**: For odd r >= 5, if a graph on rn vertices has girth r, does it have at most n^r copies of Cr? This **remains OPEN** for r > 5.
mathContext: The r = 5 case is exactly our pentagon theorem (triangle-free + no C4 = girth 5). For r = 7, 9, 11, ..., the conjecture is open. Flag algebras become more complex.

title: Summary Theorems
content: **erdos_24_pentagon_theorem**: The main result. **erdos_24_extremal_exists**: Proves the extremal graph exists and achieves the bound.
mathContext: The existence theorem constructs the extremal graph explicitly using balancedBlowupC5, showing the bound is tight. This completes the solution to Problem #24.
